media:group.media:title: Armenian parliament targets opposition lawmakers
media:group.media:description:
üìç Armenia‚Äôs parliament debates lifting immunity for opposition lawmakers Seyran Ohanyan and Artsvik Minasyan over corruption-related charges. üìç Detained businessman Samvel Karapetyan is suing two ruling party lawmakers for defamation over claims linking him to Russia and activity against the state. üìç The Armenian Patriarch of Istanbul explains the Patriarchate‚Äôs closure during Pashinyan‚Äôs visit last month, citing procedural issues and a silent protest over the prime minister‚Äôs criticism of the Catholicos.

entry.title: Can Azerbaijan be prosecuted for war crimes?

media:group.media:title: Can Azerbaijan be prosecuted for war crimes?
media:group.media:description:
Steve Swerdlow, human rights lawyer and professor at the University of Southern California, examines the human rights implications of Azerbaijan‚Äôs 2022 attack on Armenia and the ongoing border aggression. Drawing on international law and his own fieldwork, Swerdlow argues that these actions constitute a crime, and calls for accountability through the International Criminal Court or universal jurisdiction, a legal principle that allows states or international organizations to prosecute individuals. He also highlights the dangers of entrenched hate speech and Armenophobia in Azerbaijan, and makes the case for international pressure, legal action, and a recommitment by Armenia to its human rights obligations as part of its path forward.
0:00- Introduction 0:34- Azerbaijan‚Äôs September 2022 invasion of Armenia 2:41- The crime of aggression 4:29- Azerbaijan will be held to account 5:23- Will Azerbaijan dodge international accountability forever? 8:46- Effects of hatred being inculcated into Azerbaijani society 11:51- Importance of Armenia upholding democratic principles

entry.title: Armenia reaffirms backing for regional transit under its sovereign control

media:group.media:description:
üìç Armenia reaffirms support for unblocking regional transport links under Yerevan‚Äôs sovereignty, responding to reports of a U.S.-backed plan that aligns with the Crossroads of Peace initiative. üìç Armenia‚Äôs parliament has passed a law enabling the state to take control of the Electricity Networks of Armenia, despite objections from the country‚Äôs opposition. üìç Armenia expands and simplifies its housing support program to aid displaced families from Nagorno-Karabakh, extending eligibility and deadlines through 2027. üìç Why this is the moment to accelerate Armenia-India ties- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2eIeV6xASFk

entry.title: What‚Äôs really behind Armenia‚Äôs alleged insurrection?

media:group.media:title: What‚Äôs really behind Armenia‚Äôs alleged insurrection?
media:group.media:description:
In this episode of _Insights_ , host Eric Hacopian covers the arrest of Archbishop Ajapahyan and the deeper implications of the alleged coup plot. He examines why the state's case raises suspicion, what gives it credibility, and how foreign interference may be involved. Additionally, Hacopian takes a look at the shameful rhetoric dominating Armenian politics, and what it reveals about the country's direction.
